results.content:
De nuevo otro curso sin subtítulos en mi idioma nativo, por lo que me tengo que ir "apañando" pero no estoy obligado a hacerlo si no tengo una formación específica en otro idioma.

Si una empresa de tu país (en este caso española) te "obliga" a realizar una determinada formación, lo mínimo sería que se preocupase de darte dicha formación en tu idioma nativo (al menos con subtítulos) o formarte en dicho idioma.

La conclusión más importante que saco es que el modelo Udemy está bien para estudiar de forma autodidacta pero por parte de una empresa enviarte enlaces de Udemy no es darte formación, es decirte "mírate esto y te buscas la vida", sin la posibilidad de poder preguntar al formador en tiempo real ni preocupación por evaluar tu progreso. Y para eso ya existen YouTube y otras plataformas más o menos especializadas. 

Lamentablemente todo esto influye negativamente en mi calificación final del curso.

results.content:
Good introduction into J2EE. 

Presented JAX-RS services could be more RESTFul, i,e, compare POST .../todos/new
https://restfulapi.net/resource-naming/ ->  Never use CRUD function names in URIs

Good programming practices could be  shown more, e.g. Optional could be returned from the method instead of null.

I am not sure if caching example actually works as expected ( compare 300 - JAX-RS in Practice - Caching with CacheControl and Etags vs https://abhishek-gupta.gitbook.io/rest-assured-with-jaxrs/jax-rs-for-power-users-part-ii#etag-in-action) => looks like random ETag is returned for the same object what prevents it from caching

To sum up, it's not bad, it's quite good it could be even better.

results.content:
So for all the 1-3.5 stars here, I just have this to say, the instructor makes it very easy to understand the course with very simple POJO classes, that you should already know and have the basics Java 101 for before taking this course. If you expect the instructor to live code such simple code onscreen for you to comprehend where all the pieces fit together, then you are in the wrong course. As the name implies, this is an enterprise level way of developing software(distributed systems to be precise, especially with EVENTS); and to develop any enterprise software, you should already have had an intermediate to advance level mastery of your programming language of choice.
For those complaining about the accent, you have also succeeded in exposing the fact that you have not been developing enterprise software on a team for long or never; because if you have, you would have ran into working with all kinds of offshore team members from all walks of life across the globe. Once you are put in that kind of environment, and start working with other team members from other countries and cultures you are unfamiliar with, you will quickly train your ears to adapt to other accents and understand 90% of what is being communicated within a matter of hours. My advice, try watching the course a second time, if you had issue with his accent, and I promise you you will understand him this time around. 
Better yet, before taking any Udemy course, you owe it to yourself to watch the free preview(s), if provided, to get an idea of what you are getting into.

If you are totally new to Java, take the time to go through a more detailed Core Java material, and come back to this one.
Now granted, the course touches on the fundamentals of JavaEE. No single course on Udemy can cover all JavaEE topics in advance. There are lots of materials out there dedicated to almost all the components the encapsulate the core and/or other JEE implemented servers (both full fledged and web profiles servers alike). Want more on CDI, EJBs, JSF, EM, etc. look it up online and you will find gazillion materials dedicated to just that topic.
Keep up the good work, sir!

results.content:
Um dos melhores cursos da Udemy que já iniciei.
O instrutor utiliza uma metodologia cativante, primeiro te mostra uma pequena aplicação funcionando e depois vai te explicado cada detalhe do que  foi feito em um nível bem profundo.
Já na primeira parte vai perceber o poder que o Java EE 8 tem para desenvolvimento de aplicações Restfull modernas. 
Pra quem conhece Spring vai ver que as duas tecnologias são bem parecidas na sua forma de utilizar. 
Vale muito a pena se inscrever neste curso, não vão se arrepender.

results.content:
Il corso offre un'infarinatura di base per chi non sa nulla di Java EE. il 90% degli argomenti è trattato chiaramente e con esempi, ma altri avrebbero meritato almeno un cenno.
La qualità audio è penosa, e un paio di video sono montati male, con dei tagli evidenti. Il codice sorgente fornito ad ogni lezione è impreciso, non coincide esattamente con quello che viene mostrato a video ma include parti già sviluppate; in questo modo è difficile seguire quello che accade a schermo, perchè bisogna fermarsi a capire cosa va implementato e cosa no.
Alcuni argomenti andrebbero approfonditi meglio, come maven o junit.
Complessivamente è un corso discreto per iniziare con Java EE.

It is a shame because I was looking forward to exploring JEE/Jakarta web applications

results.content:
At first a little annoyed by the accent by Luqman Saeed. I had little understanding acoustically for the chapter 'Contexts and Dependency Injection'. But I got used to it later. Subtitles were unfortunately crap. So I wanted to give up learning more chapters. Therefore thought of a rating of 1.5 stars.

BUT, but that would have been a big mistake ...
Section 6: Java Persistence API = awesome
Section 7: Java API for Rest Web Services = awesome
Other Sections (WebSockets, testing Java EE, Capstone Project) = awesome

Therefore 4.5 stars from me. Very good course, learned a lot!

Il corso è ottimo, mi è piaciuto tantissimo e  mi piace parecchio l'insegnante. Però non è semplice capirne la pronuncia e i sottotitoli automatici non fanno altro che complicare la situazione, bisognerebbe sistemare questo problema. Inoltre , ho avuto parecchi problemi nel far eseguire i programmi studiati nel corso, chissà per motivi di impostazioni di base, configurazione del sistema operativo, versioni di software etc... e non sono soddisfatto al 100% specialmente per questo motivo. In pratica, la teoria che ho studiato non ha funzionato. Spero comunque di risolvere questi problemi con l'aiuto del professore

results.content: É um curso Java EE completo, aborda praticamente tudo o que um interessado precisa saber, do início ao fim. O instrutor realmente domina o assunto e não deixa dúvidas disso. Para quem quer aprender a tecnologia o curso é mais do que apropriado. O curso baseia os exemplos com a utilização do Payara Micro Server mas não tive dificuldades em adaptar para outros servidores JEE. A explicação é muito detalhada e chega a ser até cansativa em alguns momentos pelo esforço repetitivo que o instrutor faz em transmitir a informação de modo que até o menos familiarizados possam entender. O áudio é um pouco ruim, havendo ruídos de fundo durante boa parte das aulas e não ouve um cuidado de filtrar sibilos e estalos captados pelo microfone durante as explicações do instrutor. De forma geral ficou acima das minhas expectativas e recomendo o curso sem dúvida alguma.

results.content: Great course that covers a lot of topics. Luqman is a great instructor and his knowledge on the subject is evident. The quality of the videos was also quite good. Perhaps one of the points that can be improved is the use of the Windows 10 whiteboard by the instructor. I think that if a slideshow presentation was used instead of the whiteboard it would provide a clearer result. But, overall this was a great course and I would certainly recommend it to anybody that is interested in Enterprise Java.

results.content: About halfway done with the course. I jump around a lot. I use tomee + eclipse for all my java needs, but the code he writes can be used on just about any compliant server. The hardest part was probably setting up my environment, but once you get it running you are pretty much good to go. I think he is probably my favorite developer, and I hope he doesn't get discouraged by any negative reviews. If you are taking this course don't get down if the server dosen't start, because there is still a lot of information to learn. I will absolutley continue using this course as a resource for building JEE applications

results.content:
After Section 4, the course may as well be an automated PowerPoint presentation with audio. The subtitles are automatically generated and as such, are woefully incorrect most of the time (it's basically useless). The source code is provided at the end of each lesson, but he does not code along with you (as in, he does not code from scratch, but instead opens a pre-made project and then modifies the code a little to turn annotations on or off to see what happens). This might be fine if the source code is updated with each new lesson, so at least you can review the code and figure it out on your own, but no, it's the source code for all of the lessons in that section (future lessons as well as past). It's up to you to narrow down which files he worked on for that particular lesson by going back and using the video. Obviously, you can follow along by opening the source code and attempt to open the files as he brings them up on the screen but I found this to be terribly inefficient and unwieldy. For instance, he opens the XHTML page for a brief second, then opens a different tab, so you need to pause the video and locate the exact second in which that page was shown, then locate and open the file, then resume video... You see my point, I hope. 

Also, it seems you are expected to have some knowledge of web development. Course description states that only basic Java is needed. As of lesson 83, he hasn't explained how to use XHTML with your JEE code so you'll have to figure that out on your own. This is probably not difficult but you might have expected that he would have covered the subject by then. 

Some may say that I'm expecting too much handholding and perhaps you are right, but what is the point of a video lecture if lecture notes and the source code would have done as much? At least with lecture notes, I could easily flip a page back and forth instead of needing to pinpoint something he said by navigating the video progress bar. 

Luqman, if you're reading this, I do not mean to offend, you seem nice enough. I do have a recommendation however. Perhaps a good stopgap measure to remedy the above situation is to include a summary video at the end of each section where you code a project from scratch and use all of the material from the section. With that said, thank you for publishing and recording these lessons.

response.content:
Hi Siu,
First off thanks for your candid review and opinion. I'm not sure which section 4 you refer to but the section 4 of THIS course titled Getting Your Feet Wet with Java EE is a section where we create a simple Todo app with the Java EE platform, in code. 

The last couple of lectures of the section are then dedicated to teaching the basic theory behind the Java EE platform, like definitions of the various pot-soup acronyms that tend to intimidate new users.

All in all, the goal of the course is to balance between effectively helping you learn software development with the Java EE platform and making the content accessible and easy to follow.

I'm sorry if your expectations were not met. Your review will help create better future courses. 
Thank you a lot for your custom. Have a great day.
